content:
er 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								I decided that Pluto should take revenge on the other planets for downgrading it.I slammed Charon into Pluto, along with a couple more Kuiper objects to make it bigger.Once it was a little bigger than Mercury, I slammed it into Mercury.Then Venus.Then Mars.Then Earth.Then, I slammed a few more Earths into it to make it larger.Then I put it up against Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune.Pluto won every time, growing ever bigger.Something odd happened when I slammed it into Jupiter, though. The two bodies started to orbit each other very quickly, Jupiter slowly getting torn apart into little fragments, orbiting Pluto.Then, Pluto ate all of the fragments.But it didn't stop there.Pluto, even though it was leauges smaller than the sun, flew directly toward it.Upon impact, the sun exploded, creating a massive nebula. At the center of it was Pluto, unharmed.I kept slamming it into suns.Eventually, I slammed it into VY Canis Majoris.Then, lag.When the lag ended, I zoomed back into Pluto, still alive. But something was different.Instead of a supermassive planet/star thing, there was a small glowing dot.Was it a black hole? I don't know.It was no larger than the sun, and glowing a pleasant red glow, but distorted light near it like a black hole.I saved it, and put it into a stock solar system.It immediately ate the sun, and sent every other body flying out into interstellar space at 10000 km/s.I dubbed this cataclysmic object Pluto Nova.10/10 would make Pluto destroy the universe again

content:
ber 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have privately and publicly alpha tested this game since Alpha 8.3.  I bought the original US in 2009.  The pace of development on US2 is amazing.  I personally have a fascination in space, astrophysics and any science that governs the workings of the universe from particles to galaxies... and the original US was one of the most amazing things I had ever seen...  Even in its now-considered retro theme, it was an opportunity to see all my knowledge, applied, in the universe, for the very first time, in a free sandbox.  Now we have US2, and I cant explain how great this program is.This is one of those games that cannot be matched by anything else.  I have run US2 on several computers, 4 to be precise, and it has run exceptionally on all of them, ranging from potatoes to near 6GHz monsters.  I would say 90% of US2's features have been implemented in this year alone.  This game always make me wonder, "Imagine US2 next month!  It will be TEN times better!".  US2 devs are open to suggestions and are quick to respond to your questions on the US2 forums.  The US2 community is like that of nowhere else.It really is amazing how many features are in this game...  I mean, most of them you will rarely use because you are too busy wrecking the universe and smashing stuff together!  The main reason I think people hesitate to buy this game (if they hesitate at all), is because it is in alpha...  Sure, there are a few bugs.  They are not game-breaking though, and the game runs flawlessly on default settings.  Thats why we alpha tested it waaaay before it came out on steam, to get the diamond of US2 as perfect as we could.This really is my lifetime favourite game.  Even in Alpha 8.3, when the devs accepted my alpha testing form, it was one of, if not the most, exciting thing ever.  I was one of just a handful of people around the world with US2.  Now in Alpha 16, you can experience that, but nearly 2x more jaw-dropping excitement and wow-factoryness! (according to the version numbers!).  Every single update they improve the game so much, I sit there, universe sandboxing, jaw dropped.  It is a truly amazing experience to play a game like this, this totally unique game, like nothing I had seen before.A really important thing I would like to mention... If you dont know, US2 developers are working hard on (at some point, soon) adding SPH.  That stands for (S)omething i forgot, (P)article (H)ydrodynamics.  Go have a look on youtube, it is a simulation of the planet in many different particles.  This means it can break up when under tidal stress, and deform awesomely in collisions!  They are going to implement this into the 3-D already complex simulation of US2.  And you thought the game was already amazing!

content:
26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Universe Sandbox isn’t a game per se; there are no bosses, aims or levels, merely an accurate model of astronomical bodies for you to fiddle with. It’s really more of a toy :O – the virtual equivalent of a configurable orrery, except hugely more complex than any mechanical system.  That complexity is one of the key attractions that Universe Sandbox possesses. Using the vast range of variables and tools at your disposal you can create some enormously convoluted displays of physics, bending cosmic laws to your will out of nothing more than a desire to see pretty patterns form on your screen :). You can move galaxies around so that they tear themselves apart beautifully, casting off clouds of stars into the abyss as part of their death throes.

content:
er 2, 2015
Early Access Review
Introduction Universe Sandbox ² is a physics-based simulator from eight person team, Giant Army. Universe Sandbox ² is, as you’d expect, a sandbox simulation and therefore you can do pretty much whatever you want within the game’s limitations. Would you like to see what happens to our Solar System when the force of gravity is doubled? You can do that! Want to know what Earth would look like after the moon collided with it? You can find out!Full Disclosure: A review copy was provided by the developer.Presentation Universe Sandbox ² is a good looking simulator. While the textures aren’t great if you zoom in right up to them they do generally look good. The models are all high quality and the visual effects in the game are absolutely brilliant. The developers have done a good job at making the game look as realistic as possible without making it too PC power hungry. As well as looking pretty the game’s appearance is functional. The UI is fairly basic and it doesn’t stick out like a sore thumb but it manages to give the user all the information and options needed to enjoy the simulator. You’ve also got the option to have visible orbits, trails, labels etc. which when on give the user a lot of information but when off allow for some great screenshots to be taken.Gameplay I’m not sure gameplay is really the right word for Universe Sandbox ² but I’ll run with it anyway. It’s quite difficult to talk about Universe Sandbox ²’s gameplay as it’s very much what you make of it. For example, if you spend all of your time creating functioning solar systems you’re going to have a rather different experience to someone who mindlessly smashes planets into each other. Those two cover one of the main ways to enjoy the simulation, creating your own scenarios. You’re given access to all of the objects in the game and you can manipulate them however you want to. As well as choosing where to place them relative to other celestial bodies you’re also given a great deal of customisation options for each celestial body such as what materials make up most of its mass or how much mass the celestial body actually has. You can also change what kind of climate planets have through the same menu as the other options or by simply moving the celestial bodies closer or further away from other bodies which have an influence on them.The other way to enjoy Universe Sandbox ² is to simply run the scenarios which the simulator comes with such as an accurate model of our solar system or a collision between two versions of Jupiter! This is really for those, like myself, who just enjoy watching that kind of thing and of course like watching planets smash into each other. I mean, who wouldn’t enjoy watching two planets smashing into each other? There are already loads of scenarios available in the game and more are being added. Like you can when creating your own scenarios, you’re able to do whatever you want with these scenarios too such as add more planets to your scenario or edit the materials a celestial body is made of.Miscellaneous You have complete control over how fast the simulation is, you can have each real second represent anything from a millisecond to billions of years.Universe Sandbox ² has a nice, relaxing soundtrack which fits nicely with calm simulations and contrasts perfectly with huge collisions.The celestial bodies in the game range from small asteroids to supergiant stars and black holes. There are even some human sized objects in the game including the Monolith from 2001.The eight person team consists of a numerical physicist, a climate scientist and an astrophysicist as well as ‘regular’ game developers.While Universe Sandbox ² isn’t too taxing on your GPU you are going to need a pretty beefy CPU to get a good frame rate on some of the more complex simulations.Verdict Worth Purchasing. Universe Sandbox ² is a realistic and interesting physics-based sandbox from Giant Army with good graphics and a lot to do. It may not offer much to your average gamer but for those with a real fascination with space it’s a real treat. It may be a bit pricey so for those average gamers I’d suggest holding off for some kind of discount but if you’re a space nut like myself then it’s worth it.No drama, Just Reviews.El K.

content:
ber 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is a very good reminder of the precarious balance in which the universe hangs. I mean, all it takes is a red dwarf star to s̶p̶a̶w̶n̶  mysterously appear out of nowwhere and crash into the sun in order to cause a cataclysmic event that causes a b̶e̶a̶u̶t̶i̶f̶u̶l̶  truely awful explosion of the entire solar system. This game also makes you appreciate that the sun doesn't suddenly become a billion times more dense and turn into a black hole in which all life as we know it is killed most horribly. And we are most certainly glad the moon doesn't collide with an exact replica of itself and slowly destroy the Earth with pieces of debris; at least until another moon collides with the earth because the small pieces of debris were taking too long. And yet, amidst all this potential destruction, here we are. And I still can't hit Earth with golf balls fired from Mars.Edit: Though as it turns out I can hit Earth with Mars fired from Mars, and if fired with a weak enough force I can hit Mars, with Mars fired from Mars.

content:
er 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								The universe was created in 7 days by our holy entity Megatruck, blessings upon Him, henceforth to be named God.On the first day, God pressed the 'new' button, thereby errasing the Solar system from existence. At first there was nothing, and God said,"Let there be light." He had to rummage through the star folder. An then there was light, to be more precise a small white star that God had destined to be named, "Cheese Ball." And God looked upon Cheese Ball and saw that it was good, made out of Hydrogen and Helium rather than powdered cheddar. God looked upon the area surrounding Cheese Ball,  and figured it to be desolate. And lo, a small circular rock was placed by our heavenly father that circled around Cheese Ball with great vigor. It had a sad existence, useless to life, and was christened with the title, "Maxwell the firey spacedot." God had thought it weird to have a perfect circular orbit, so God clicked on Maxwell the firey spacedot's tab and revealed a metric forkton of settings. After twiddling with them for a few hours, and finally stopping that infernal white trail coming from Maxwell the fiery spacedot for some reason, called off the universe and saved it away in a file named, "srgblga." On the second day, Maxwell the fiery spacedot's orbit was appropriately ovaloid. God then demmanded, "There should be life here!" No one was going to do it for Him, He was God afterall, the lazy trunkbasket.And He should stop capitalizing His pronouns, it's annoying. Stop it. So, he found out Cheese Ball's Goldilocks zone, placed a nice white planet down, screwed with it's orbit, decided the pre-generated name Rxnamien didn't fit this gift of his, and called it, "Nimrod." And so Nimrod was, for a few seconds, and then God added water to it's makeup. He waited. Then, God bellowed, "Why snt there life? Water is the foundation of life as I know it!" He then accelerated time by a few millenia, slowed it down again, and gave Nimrod a moon, because habitable planets all have moons, right? And this moon, oh what a moon. it was a golden yellow, a shiny, magnificent ball, worthy to a god such as he. Honoring it with the title, "Dorfff," God wondered at the beauty of a night sky adorned by Dorfff.  He then commanded, "GROW SOME LIFE MEDAMMIT." and overwrote srgblga and closed the game in a heaveny furor. On the third day, God's still trying to create some life in dis birch. On the fourth day, he finally got an atmosphere, but jack anything else. On the fifth day, God is trying to BALANCE THE GREENHOUSE DEAR ME TOO MUCH TOO LITTLE WHYYYY. On the sixth day, God decided it would be nice to ploomp some gas giants in the distance. And lo, Garumpf and Smorgasbord were born. They were useless, but adorned with moons, ranged from planet sized to are-you-even-trying sized. Time to get funky with their orbits, or so.  on the seventh day, God FINALLY CREATES SUM LIL' CITIES THEY ARE SO CUTE. Despite being blurry dots of white only visible on the dark side of Nimrod, God feels an overwhelming sense of accomplishment. God saves over srgblga, and watches the cosmos he has created. He then gets bored and lobs a red dwarf at Cheese Ball,thus crating a cataclysmic event starting with planets losing their orbit and ending in a supernova, obliterating everything, including the framerate. God closes the game, and eats some pizza. And thus ends the story of God. TL/DR: Read it please unless you don't like short stories about me being a malevolent being creating life and destroying it. 10/10 would cry in joy at the miracle of life and then meniacly laugh as they all burn to spacedust again.

content:
y 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								First off I definitely recommend this game, but like all games it has downsides.This may be a bit of a read, but where is a good review without its detail right?One of the first things I noticed, when you buy this game that's it, you have the entire game, no special objects I have to buy, if I want to throw a football with the mass of a sun at a teapot the size of our earth, then I can do it as soon as I purchase this game. Which I can tell would appeal to most people.I'll go over my favourite aspect of the game now, but to save me rambling on about every little feature I enjoy, I'll make a list after this. The thing I love most about this game, is the creativity and curiosity this game brings. As I mentioned before; but who could imagine that you can make a football our solar systems apocalypse?! One things this game does  indeed do very well, is catching the interest and curiosity of people, but also allowing quite a fair bit of creativity.As I said before I will now make a quick list of all the other things I enjoy a lot about this game:-Black Holes (you'll spend a lot of your time, if not most of it messing around with black holes).-Watching what happens when our sun evolves.-Blowing up every item in the game.-What happens if's (with the earth especially).-Trying to make another earth from scratch.-Turning a teapot into a sun.-Creating a Solar System.-Creating a very small galaxy.-Messing around with the milkyway.-Making a potential universe descructing object.-Watching the beautiful simulations, with the beautiful music playing.Those pretty much cover what I'll be doing and you'll most likely be doing in this game, but the things is, I know there are some more things in the game I haven't started to look at yet, which I will do very soon; they also keep updating this game, so I am always on the look out for any interesting additions they put in.Alright, so like with every game, it has a few downsides. Here are a few.After about three hours of playing and testing things out, I started to feel a bit bored and I felt as if I had tried everything that is worth doing (blowing up the earth a million times, and putting a black hole at the centre of our solar system). So what I would say the developers is this, perhaps for a future game, or to just make a big update for this one, think about what more content could you add into this game, or how much more detail can you go into with what happens in space, just to add those extra few hours of interesting gameplay; that being said, I could probably play this for a maximum of two amazing hours, creating my own universe, and creating several apocalyptic situations, then a minimum of a week and a bit, of a break before wanting to play and do that all again. A small suggestion for what you could add; add or make a load more options of what if situations, and perhaps more interesting or ambitious what ifs, like what if aliens were real and invaded our solar system, or what if earth advanced space travel so much they were travelling around our solar system as easy as people can get on a bus now. Maybe too ambitious but you start to see my point.A final thing, only small, and not the most important downside, but something I certainly picked up upon, and thought, hmm, would have been better with this; is the whole black holes being the most destructive force situation. In this game, all they are, are huge slingshots. Now, I know black holes do something to do with shooting objects out at incredibly high speeds, but I'm no expert. However I also know, or at least have heard from people who are meant to be experts, that under the great force of the gravity a black hole has, objects that are pulled towards it are torn to pieces by the strength of the gravitational pull; and for a lot of people interested in black holes, this is one main thing they focus on; the destructive power it brings wherever it goes. In this game, as I said before, I only see a slingshot, a bunjee jump, to me, a black hole in this game is far from being as deadly and chaotic as they are said to be by experts. I'm almost sure this is to do with the design of the game, that limits this feature, or to do with the time it might have taken to make these extra small details added in; but considering the large majority who will spend most of their time playing around with black holes; I STRONGLY suggest to the developers, that again, either in a very future version of this game, or a large update later on, that there is some sort of design that let's us all see that truly great power a black hole holds, and how merciless it can be.Those are the two main downsides in this game for me. Although, in conclusion, I certainly recommend this game, it is still fairly new, and having regular updates, (mainly the little fixtures us gamers don't notice very much), but it can give a lot, answer a lot of your curious questions about space, and it is still extremely fun to play. Definitely worth it, and quite frankly, you can never get bored of tossing the moon at earth. Oh, and Developers, if any of you read this, of course, great game, very well done, so congratulations, but also take into account what improvements that I have said could be there in the future.Thanks!

content:
ry 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								After my gameplay of Universe Sandbox 2, I decided to write a review on one of the most fantastic games in the universe in my opinion.- Universe Sandbox 2 is a very detailed simulation. It show this in the craters that forms after you collide an object into another, in the elevation as seen by adding water onto the surface of the object, and also in the accuracy on the simulation of gravitational pulls of bodies.- Universe Sandbox 2 contains a simple, efficient design as compared to the original Universe Sandbox. "Home" dispays system-included simulations under "Open" and also displays templates under "Create". You also have a "Learn" section where you learn different interesting facts of some interesting or bizzare objects in the Universe. The Properties Menu show the basic information of an object, climate information of the object, and the materials that made up the object.- Universe Sandbox 2 controls the timestep in lagging times. If the game thinks that the frame rate is too low, it automatically controls the timestep slower in order to make your experience with the game better.- The Giant Army is a friendly group that helps your solve your technical issues in Universe Sandbox 2. If you have any problems with your experience in Universe Sandbox 2, the developers are there to help. Just make sure that you post your problem on to either the Steam discussion group or the Universe Sandbox forums and they will (usually) give you a reply within 15 hours.

content:
er 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								[!DISCLAIMER!] I always talk about how great this game is in my review. However, if this simulation or space genre doesn't interest you, you shouldn't be wasting your time reading these reviews in the first place.Anyways...ONWARDS! TO MY REVIEW!<------------------------------------------------------------------------------->Wow.This Is a good game.I mean, C'mon. That's a TOTAL understatement. All 65.5 Hours (and counting) i've spent on this game have been spent doing the same exact ♥♥♥♥ over and over again. That's how good this game is. You can spend a few days straight doing the same thing, and never get tired or bored of it. Want to smash a planet into Earth? SURE! Go ahead! Jupiter's just waiting to gobble up that son of a ♥♥♥♥♥. Want to smash another planet into Earth? WHY NOT? Neptune's getting pretty hungry too! Hell, why not restart the simulation and throw Uranus at Earth too.Screw it. Double tap that baby and throw The Sun at Uranus just to make sure anything on Earth AND Uranus is erased.The amount of fun that can be had playing this game is endless.This game has amazing visuals and (With some of the more recent updates) a beautiful, dynamic soundtrack that really accompanies the scale and feel of space. Perhaps not on a lonely or empty sense, but on an epic and awe-inspiring sense. But i'm sure you could care less about both. Just what can you do on this game, exactly?Well.You can, as i said, smash planets together with astoundingly awesome collision physics.Watch Galaxies collide.Admire the gravitational lensing effects of blackholesTerraform entire planets. (Then crash them into another planet)Disrupt the rings around Saturn with a larger celestial bodyHell, you can even spawn in the New Horizons Space craft and throw it at pluto, if you're so inclined.. . .That only barely scratches the SURFACE of the amount of features this game provides.I'll leave the rest for you to discover when you play this gorgeous game yourself!If you like space, or physics, this game is a great way to learn a little something too. Some of the detailed and functioning laws and physics in this simulation are not only good to look at, but also surprisingly accurate and can teach you a little basics.It's ♥♥♥♥ing amazing.Buy it.It's worth your money.

content:
25, 2015
Early Access Review



YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



Game: Universe Sandbox ²Genre: Space SimulatorDeveloper: Giant Army Publisher: Giant Army Copy supplied by developer Universe Sandbox ² is the sequel to the 2011 space simulator, developed and published by Giant Army. GRAPHICSThe game has improved a lot graphically compared to the original: there are many more particle effects, better textures, climate changes that affect the look of each planet and also great performance that makes this game playable on basically every system there is. GAMEPLAYIn this simulator, you can move planets, change their properties, spawn supernovas or black holes and see what happens. In addition to what was already in the first game, there is a more user-friendly UI, the possibility to modify the materials and climate of the different planets and many more to be added in the future. But you have to remember that this is not really a game, so you set your own goals: maybe you want to destroy the entire galaxy with a giant black hole, maybe you want Mars to transform into a supernova that burns other planets. The possibilities are endless. SOUNDThey have just added a soundtrack to the game, which is beautiful: it makes all the science and experiments more enjoyable and helps deliver a relaxing experience. REPLAYABILITYThe possibilities are truly endless, and as soon as you get the hang of it, you will start modifying all the different planets just to see what happens. Lovers of space simulators will play this for many years to come, also because the developers are constantly updating the game. I like to think that this is more of an actual software, than it is a game. If you like everything that is related to space, than this is a must-buy. It's a great sequel, and a relaxing game. Story: n/a

content:
er 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've wanted this game for ages, pretty much since the day it was released but I finally saved up enough money to buy it for myself. And I've got to say, having played for 3 hours, my first impression is that this is absolutely incredible. The sheer joy of creating my own planets and putting them in to our Solar System, or putting a sun-sized football as a replacement for the Sun. The amount you learn in this game is mind-blowing, and makes you realise the size of the universe. It's almost scary. And of course, who doesn't love a bit of destruction? It's hilarious throwing moon-sized teapots at Earth and throwing one planet at another. If you're not sure about this game, get it. There's nothing like experiencing it for yourself, watching videos has nowhere near as much excitement and thrill as it is to do it yourself. You may think "oh god I'm spending £18.99", and so did I. But just think of the incredible detail and the amount of possibilities in this sim. It's in Alpha! The game isn't even finished yet and it's already better than any game I've spent £20 on, by the time it's finished I reckon the possibilities will be endless and the experience will be like no other. For the people complaining about boredom after 30 minutes, remember - it is in Alpha. By full release I don't think you'll ever be bored again!Seriously impressed.

content:
, 2016
Early Access Review
								"The Earth is a very small stage in a vast cosmic arena" -Carl Sagan.Universe Sandbox 2 at its core is a mere physics simulator. Simple enough but the vastness of the scale is overwhelming. While quite the fantastic computer program alone, I strongly urge that one would enjoy it with the HTC Vive.  One may spend a moment above the Solar system and marvel at the orrery precision of the paths taken by the planets revolving in the middle of your room, and then fly in on your favorite planet to scrutinize at a naturalistic scale as a true behemoth careens by at a dwarfing 1:1 perspective.  Fire a few asteroids here and there to examine the unwavering momentum of whatever hapless body pulled it out of a straight trajectory, but you will find yourself depositing stars nearby such as Rigel which consider the entire Solar System to be a mere morsel.  There are things out there that are truly and terrifyingly massive.I have always had a passion for astronomy so this game is quite the treat.  My 60-year-old father has also taken to the game with an astonishing fervor so I bought him his very own Vive so he would stop bumming around my place hogging my video games. Alas, I have shown many friends and family members this game, often as an induction into VR as I set up a gorgeous scene and put them game on pause to then have them put the headset on to blow their minds.  My favorite scenario is a few planets being vaporized as they rotate perilously close to a violent neutron star.  I find myself teaching others about "what the ♥♥♥♥ am I looking at?" and "why is it doing that thing?" and "this stuff really exists!?" and "why is space so damn beautiful?".  Dispensing moments of pure astonishment has become a past time. I've become the Carl Sagan of my living room as I take people on my Ship of the Imagination to show them what vast ocean teems beyond their small island of which they know.If you hold the beauty of the cosmos in reverence, I suggest you try this game out on VR. Nothing quite compares to having lunch in orbit around the Earth and then releasing a generous salvo of Moons at it and reveling in your wanton destruction. Then you add hydrogen gas until the Earth becomes a gas giant, then a brown dwarf, full star, neutron star, black hole, then grow that black hole until its more massive than the observable universe and then you win the game! Mwuahahaha!!  Who wants to be Space God when you can be Space Devil? The universe is your sandbox.Dad quit hogging my sandbox.

content:
19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Universe Sandbox 2 is one of those games whose title describes what you're about to buy.It offers you a complete freedom in creating your own little world and do with it what your heart desires. And that world is not limited to just planets or asteroids, but extends to objects as small as a pair of dice and as large as the biggest galaxy in our universe. You are essentially playing as a cosmological god, creating and destroying; terraforming and making places go extinct.This is one of the best if not the best space games available out there and although there is not true storyline or purpose in it, you will definitely be able to enjoy creating and destroying things as long as you have a bit of imagination.I've used this game as a tool to teach about astronomy, astrophysics and even history and have definitely enjoyed every moment of my time in this game.It is still not perfect and far from being the ultimate space sandbox, but it is as close to the ultimate space game as you can currently get.The team is very dedicated to making this game great and is very quick to respond to bugs, comments or concerns.Give this a go, you won't regret it.Check out my 100s of videos of this title here:https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL9hNFus3sjE7jgrGJYkZeTpR7lnyVAk-xHere's one of the recent examples where I recreated Skyrim universe using the game:

content:
ber 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a very interesting game, especially for those who are interested in Astrology and Physics on a Cosmic level. Despite being fairly easy on graphics and the CPU (unless you go nuts with the amount of simulated objects, time scale, or try to zoom in on a supernova), this will accurately simulate the size, position, movment, mass rotation, general appearance, temperature, magnetic fields, basic composition, and gravitational fields of known stars, planets, planetoids, asteroids, black holes etc. In addition to being packed with pre-made simulations of the Solar System (major planets only, planets and major moons, all moons, or even every known object in the solar system - there is a surprising amount of them) you can change everything that is simulated at will. Alter the positions, rotations, from the size and mass down to the composition and temperature, everthing is adjustable. You can remove and place objects at whim, either standing still or with a predetermined vector. You can even mess with their mass and composition by manually adding material to them - add enough hydrogen to the sun and it will turn into a blue star! The game also simulates collisions between all the objects to a limited degree, considering the scale of the collisions. This truly is a facinating creation that I look forward to seeing grow and develop.

content:
er 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have only played this game in VR, and it is truly an amazing experience. The the scale of these astronomical objects is staggering. Shrank down to 1:1 scale to marvel at the size of the earth/moon. Created a betelgeuse on either side for lighting. After about fifteen minutes, I started to notice that they were getting closer together. Looked away from my little sytstem I'd created and saw space warping around the edges. Flipped out and frantically started flying out as the two stars started to collide in slow motion behind me, walls of nuclear fire closing in from either side. Escaped just before they went supernova, leaving behind a really pretty planetary nebula. 10/10 would use betelgeuse for lighting again.That said, a *lot* of the features have not been implemented or don't work fully in VR, and the tools are really very clumsy-- or example, the dispenser doesn't work very well or very precisely at all, and scaling the view while it's locked onto a planet makes everytthing disappear into the distance for some reason. It's incredibly difficult to actually create anything stable (near-impossible really) and very, very easy to go mad with power and start bombarding everything with moons which is... cathartic, but not necessisarily productive.

content:
ry 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								"I'll show you!" you sputter in rage, spittle rolling out the corner of your mouth. "I'll show all of you!" You flee out of the conference hall, clutching your precious work to your chest, tears of shame and rage streaming down your face, as you storm away from the Imperial Society for Impossible Science. (Yes, the initialism is under review pending recent geopolitical developemnts.)Alone in your laboratory, in your Victorian mansion, at the top of the mountain, in the middle of a thunderstorm, and other such idioms, you try to return to your experiments, your work, but soon find yourself lost in dreams of revenge towards your former colleagues. Friends, you thought, though you now know better. Their peals of laughter still echo in your mind. Tormented as you are, you finally reach the conclusion that only the most total, complete revenge will sate you: the total destruction of the earth itself. Life. Pah. If the end product of life are apes that cannot appreciate your brilliance, clearly the whole thing was a mistake. A mistake that you are more than happy to correct.Your newly found nihilistic passions drive you towards this most ultimate solution: to what fraction of the speed of light must you accelerate a common tiny celestial body -- a comet perhaps -- so as to totally liquify the earth's crust? It seems easy enough to calculate. Ah, but how to check your calculations? Brilliant though you are, you have been known to misplace a decimal place here and there, in your excitement. And your lone companion Igor, capable manservant though he may be, and very handy with a pickaxe in a graveyard, is hardly equal to this more intellectual task.Enter Universe Sandbox. Place celestial bodies where you like. Send them where you like. Check your calculations through simulation. Get your revenge. Because wouldn't it be embarrassing if you meant to liquify the earth, but wound up causing only yet another mass extinction?Seriously, this is lots of fun. If you wind up using this program for anything other than destroying the earth over and over and over in new and exciting ways, you are made of sterner stuff than I.It's also great for teaching young kids, at least at an intuitive level, orbital mechanics, the concept of kinetic energy, and why two planetary mass objects, when they bump into each other, behave slightly differently than two small balls rolling across the living room floor.Pro tip: if, upon witnessing the total, irretrievable extinction of all life on earth, your five-year-old daughter asks, "could this ever happen in real life," answer with something a bit more reassuring than "probably not, but you never know." That is, unless you like getting up at 2 AM every night for the better part of a month. Sigh.

Early Access Review
								I had bought the first version back in my dual-boot days (long since over), and had hoped for a Linux verson. The release of this "squared" version took me by surprise and delight. The graphics for this iteration are superb and the physics are as good as the first version, if not better. Not for everyone, of course, and while you can smash planets together in Planetary Annihilation, the physics of this sim are certainly better. Creating your very own solar system is a rewarding activity, as is smashing a Mars-sized object into the Earth and seeing if a lunar object results. You won't find a better simulation of, well, anything. VERY highly recommended.

content:
er 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Whether you want to understand how the universe currently functions or want to blow a lot of stuff repeatedly, this game can do both realistically at the same time.More seriously though ,this "game" (I'd rather call it something more special than just that, but I can't find the words.) also had a special effect on me, it made me realise how small we actually are compared to everything that is out there. It made me comprehend how fragile life really is and how special we are for being able to say that life as we know it, is precious.Thus, It has personnally enhanced my current understanding of a lot of fundemental phenomenons that I simply couldn't picture properly solely by reading texts explaining them seperately. This game is the big picture.  Just to name a few:- Picturing the Moon cycle- Seeing how the Greenhouse effect affects everything- Viewing a suprinsigly accurate explanation for the formation of the moon- Understanding how two galaxies will eventually collide - Comprehending how gravity plays a role in everything- Many many more.I wish people were as stoked to get this "game" as they are for the latests AAA titles. So that another slightly better version would come out each year. And I'd buy it wholeheartedly.

content:
er 27, 2015
Early Access Review
I've wanted this game for ages, pretty much since the day it was released but I finally saved up enough money to buy it for myself. And I've got to say, having played for only 1 hour, my first impression is that this is absolutely incredible. The sheer joy of creating my own planets and putting them in to our Solar System, or putting a sun-sized football as a replacement for the Sun. The amount you learn in this game is mind-blowing, and makes you realise the size of the universe. It's almost scary. And of course, who doesn't love a bit of destruction? It's hilarious throwing moon-sized teapots at Earth and throwing one planet at another. If you're not sure about this game, get it. There's nothing like experiencing it for yourself, watching videos has nowhere near as much excitement and thrill as it is to do it yourself. You may think "oh god I'm spending $19.99", and so did I. But just think of the incredible detail and the amount of possibilities in this sim. It's in Alpha! The game isn't even finished yet and it's already better than any game I've spent $20 on, by the time it's finished I reckon the possibilities will be endless and the experience will be like no other. 
For the people complaining about boredom after 30 minutes, remember - it is in Alpha. By full release I don't think you'll ever be bored again!

Seriously impressed.

content:
y 6
Early Access Review
								I have a very deep fetish of space related things. Universe Sandbox 1 kept me very entertained for hours, and though I do not have a ton of time in US2 it is still a great platform for those who have a deep desire to learn. It's been a great tool to use while watching documentaries, reading articles online, and just general experimentation and exploration.The ONLY thing that makes me sad about this game is the complete and total dedication to JUST being a physics simulator.  Look, I know that's the point of this program, that doesn't mean however that it's the only thing it could be used for.  Everytime I've seen a great suggestion on the forums for a feature that isn't specifically space related is, "Oh well it's a physics simulator, why would they have feature x?"The reason why they should consider features x, y, or z, is that while it's a decent physics simulator, it could be a much more powerful learning tool if they could only stop limiting theirselves with this frame of mind.This has been a retort to all manner of features such as:- Weather- A "Human" type feature such as ISS models, or small spaceships- Having places labeled with landmarks (Such as a text box showing Olympus Mons location on Mars)- Even people suggesting a grid system showing a bend in spacetime for the various planets showing their gravitation impactsI wish there was a competitor out that would take advantage of these great suggestions if US2 is not. And it's totally not just so I can plan the destruction of Alderaan.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
2
Early Access Review
								Universe Sandbox 2 is a masterfully done game. It's gameplay is deep and incredibly fun, and the graphics are surprisingly beautiful. I would reccomend it wholeheartedly. It does have flaws, but they are minor enough to not hamper my enjoyment.Pros --My favorite part of the game is the collisions, which look and feel amazing. It has never been this satisfying to launch the moon at Austrailia, vaporizing the continent and melting the earth's surface.-The soundtrack of the game is really nice, which is surprising considering it's not the game's main appeal at all.-There's more to do than just collisions. You can create solar systems, experiment with atmospheres, terraform barren planets, and much more. With enough imagination, you can do anything.-Lots of premade scenarios for you to play around with.-Easy to use UI.-It can even be educational, in some cases.-The developers seem to be great people, and communicate a lot with their fanbase.-It's very polished. The framerate is smooth and I haven't encountered many major glitchesCons--It isn't updated very often, but that's understandable for such a complex game.-The soundtrack, while beautiful, has very few tracks. Only about four or five.-The physics engine sometimes breaks down, but only if you push it too hard and often it breaks in hilarious ways.-You may lose intrest after a point, but only way after you've gotten your money's worth.Overall, it's a great game with one or two nitpicky flaws that aren't important at all.8.5/10

If you love science and especially astronomy, this game is perfect for you. It gives you enough control to make you the puppet master of your own little solar systems, once you figure out how to control them.TL;DRGood game. Destruction is fun, but not fun enough to justify a purchase unless you just want to support the devs. But it is a fantastic learning/science game for those interested.

content:
27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Do you like astronomy? Do you like space? Do you like smashing two planets together in a fiery explosion? If you answered yes to anything of these questions, then this game is for you! Universe Sandbox 2 is a simulator that lets you experiment on an astronomical level, spawning stars, moons, planets, and pulsars. Create solar sytems (or destroy them), explode stars and watch them go supernova. Its like a star gazing book, except much more fun and interactive. Plus, its real science-y, with accurate data to simulate our own solar system, or a random one... or anything, really. This is a gravity simulator at heart. Orbits, eccentricity, Inclination, velocity, etc. It comes with dozens of pre-made simulations. However, make no mistake, the rest is icing on the cake.Okay, so now its time for more specificity. Features of the game include stellar evolution, climate simulation, full body fragmentation, light pulses, saving/loading sims, bodies, galaxies (galaxies are WIP for right now), and objects. First is stellar evolution, which is the process of stars aging until they die. You could sit there and watch a star for a billion years in real-time until it dies, or just take the easy route and speed it up. Next is climate simulation, this works the best with earth for right now. When climate is enabled for a body in the simulation, the polar ice caps (specifically for earth), you can visaully see snow expand and recede as it obits the sun. At some point in the future, climate should become more fleshed out, but for the most part, the climate feature is a nice touch.I won't go over the whole list, as some are self-explanatory (and there's just too much to list anyway), but the stellar evolution, climate, and light pulses are the main ones, the rest just ties it together, and nicely, I may add. Anyway, light pulses can be "pinged" off any object you want in a simulation. Emitting a light pulse from an object will then travel through space. Watching a light pulse in real-time is probably the most amazing. It lets you visualize the speed at which light travels through space. And as far as I know, it is supposed to be accurately simulated, traveling at the speed of light. For light to travel in the "Our Solar System" simulation, from the sun to Neptune took 4 hours, just like in real life.  Same with sun-to-earth, 8 minutes. That's awesome!To sum up, if you're a fan of simulator games, and have an appreciation for astronomy, you'll probably enjoy this game/sim. There is no other simulator that does it quite like US2. The size and scale at which Universe Sanbox 2 simulates is in a league all its own. The game recieves regular updates (I was in the closed alpha before it hit steam), and the devs are actively engaged in making it better. They take time to make sure its right. Each update to the game only continues to add to an already amazing simulator! :DNow, only one last order of business: I deleted earth. Why are we still here?- 10/10 would delete earth again -

content:
6, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is truly an incredible sequel to what is one of the best simulators on Steam! This program feels more like sophisticated simulation software than an actual game in functionality, but it's incredibly user-friendly and easy to use; I use this game as a very effective visual aid for tutoring, as well as a time killer. The developers certainly don't skimp on their research, as frequent updates reflect some of the most current events in astronomy: there was a simulation of the New Horizons encounter with Pluto as the real deal was making headlines! Explorative tutorials are informative without spewing a bunch of numbers and facts all at once; yet they provide links for further enrichment, as well as pure number-crunching horsepower for those who are curious and want to tweak the gritty details and properties that bind the universe together. It's Early Access right now, but their bugs at this point are few and very far between. Updates are very frequent, and more often than not they include newly added features and simulations.The dynamic graphics for complex events such as climate patterns and planetary collisions are getting better and more refined with each update. This program offers an incredible amount of functionality, is visually appealing, and accompanied with a beautifully ambiant soundtrack. I've never been so relaxed breaking gravity and then playing billiards with all of the planets!This title completely blows its predecessor out of the water! I would highly reccommend for all those casual gamers and science fans out there. More people need to get this title - it has limitless potential for a Steam Workshop feature. For what you get, the game is set at a remarkably reasonable price - definitely worth scooping this one up!

content:
6, 2016
Early Access Review
								If someone would have told me at a young age that when I grow older, I will don the HTC Vive and start throwing around planets and suns and s***. If someone had told me that, when I was like 9-10 then I most likely would go insane and do nothing but wait for that faithful day.Even now I have a hard time accepting that I am currently playing ins space in Virtual Reality.The first time I started the game I did what everyone would have done, bombarded the Earth with its own moon repeatedly, the Earth unsurprisingly exploded into a hot light show, and it was glorious. But then my ambitions grew.I picked the random planet option prepared to spawn a gas giant a couple clicks away. Anyways, my finger slipped, and I managed to spawn it right in front of the Earth which sent it crashing into the gas giant.Before I had time to react the Earth had hit the Gas giant and my computer shut down, the Vive went completely dark; there was no sound in my earplugs, and I just stood there wondering if I just killed myself and everybody on planet Earth because I miss clicked. (This only happened once mind you, haven't had a problem with it since)Anyhow here's the VR verdict:Gameplay: Fun but lacking some functions, would like to design my own planet, sun or most of all create black holes.Graphics: It's an incredibly colorful game, you stand long in awe after putting two planets on a collision course.Smoothness: With a lot happening on the screen at once you may expect some lagging in head movements even on the most powerful of computers.Bugs\glitches: I keep being unable to use one of my controllers at startup of the game, I'm unable to choose anything but the moon. Some issues using the camera when you're trying to zoom out (Rescale), the camera moves you completely away from the planets you're attached to, only happens sometimes.Some of my specs:Geforce 1080 Founders Edition 8GB Ram i7 3,3 Ghz processor

content:
12, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is one of the most visually stunning sandbox (game) I have ever experienced. It really puts our solar system to scale and humanity to scale. The sheer size of some of the the objects in this simulation blows my mind.  The collision effects in this simulation are the best I have seen in any (game).There is something vunrable about tha because whn you collide an astriod into earth it shows how fragile our planet is and how just a little disturbance in the system can completely change earths orbit and its surface. The music really adds a sense of awe and wonder. It also adds a sense of scale. The simulations can teach you a lot about how the universe works and it also shows events that happened billions of years ago which is awesome.One of my favourite thngs to do in Universe Sandbox is putting a star called Betelguese next to our solar system. This star is huge and when I say huge I mean HUGE!. This thing dwarfs our sun. The supernova explosions are the most sprctacular features I have ever seen Anyone who is going to eperience this. Your perspective of humanity may vastly change.For an early access game 10/10. Looking forward for new improvements!

content:
er 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								Universe sandbox is a sandbox.About the universe.I know that comes as a shocker, but wait, there's more! Alright, so, this is the sequel to the original Universe Sandbox, how you make a sequel to something with no story, well, I'm not entirely sure, in that case, I think it's just a big update. But I've been wrong before, so, I dunno'.I really am just going to focus on the things they changed, not the whole game itself. And there are things that you should be able to figure out for yourself, anyway.First!The best thing, the most important thing, the thing that everyone cares about...The climate system!The destruction engine!This is ♥♥♥♥ing glorious, I swear.Even if you hate happiness, you will love this. Even if you're like, a terrorist, and they're like the children of Mister Grinch.There is terrain deformation, fragmentation, friction, gravitational destruction, it's all there, and it's all amazing.This is destruction on a scale I can recognize, and unlike the original one where things just popped, this one, they break up, they shatter, those shards, they orbit, then they break apart, and they orbit. Speaking of which,Orbital mechanics.They improved this as well.I don't know how many of you actually played the first one, but if you guys ever tried to speed things up while something was in orbit, it wouldn't treat it as speeding up, it would treat it as high velocity, so orbits will just break up super easily so you had to actually wait for things.Yeah, well, they fixed that. It works.Like it should.And like I said before didn't get to, the climate.This is improved, again, in the old one, things wouldn't change because of climate. They would just be hot or cold. And it wouldn't do anything. But in this one, water will evaporate, superhot planets turn things like iron into liquid, all that jazz, and on that note, the planets and ♥♥♥♥.Again, old one, you couldn't make random planets, and they didn't have materials, so you had to find the texture in the game or come up with your own. Yeah, well they fixed that, as well. You can make entirely random planets, with entirely random compositions, entirely random looks, and then,you can change themYou can make all kinds of ♥♥♥♥, huge iron chunks, entirely habitable island planets, gas giants, cloudy hurricane planets (kamino!), anything you can think of.There's obviously too much ♥♥♥♥ to list in here, but just trust me when I say:You can do anything.I would definitely recommend this game to sandbox game fans, and people who are into... space, I guess?(the only thing you can't do is make a rock ♥♥♥♥ but why you would even do that is beyond me)

content:
3, 2016
Early Access Review
								There have been a great many attempts to try and place the universe into a perspective, however, the problem with trying to do so is that humans don't have a comparison. for example, we KNOW that the milky was galaxy is incredibly small in the eyes of the whole universe. We don't however understand it completley. knowing is only half of it, there is no reasonable way to compare our planet to any other without treading into the realms of obsertity or disbelief in the attempt to understand how big everything is. so while i was playing i compared a black hole to a sagitarius A another black hole and my zoom out was incredible. but when you see those numbers like how big it is in our human numerical systems you can't get the hole picture because the software is designed to let you see everything and sure when you go and zoom into the black hole and you see the larger one looming amously over the event horrizon you say " hey cool that black hole is as big as 10 million of our suns." but then you look at our son and all it is is a dot in our sky. we can never fathom how big it really is when all we see is graphs and illistrations from a human point of view rather than the real point of view of how big it is. we use numbers to measure how big things are, but we don't imagine how big things really are in the real world because we will never see these things. in conclusion, this game is very well made and extremely enjoyable  but numbers and comparisons to huge things are just not helping people understand how big it is. i give this game a 10/10 ign (sorry for the rant and boring read, these were just thoughts that were bugging me. so it might not be structured as arduosly as a regular paragraph)

28, 2016
Early Access Review
								A much improved version of the first game, it vastly expands the previous featureset and improves the UI and general tooling. A must buy if you loved the first one.But, this game being Early Access, it has some rough edges that I hope will be corrected in the future, such as the still very incomplete planet surface composition and climate simulation. The simulator also still can't correctly simulate things such as tidal forces tearing satellites apart when they cross the Roche Limit, which was something I missed from the first version and I hoped would be implemented in this one.But overall the experience has been very good so far.

content:

Early Access Review
								Well, I don't have much to say, I'm speechless for all the right reasons. A game like this has been my dream for years, and now it's actually happening! You can just screw around with planets' climates and gravity and throw them at stars and whatever - and the graphics are fluid, there's virtually no bugs or glitches, absolutely amazing. Hopefully there will be even more new features in future, like the addition of extra materials like uranium to simulate the heat from an internal core, and methane, magnesium, and other chemicals and compounds to simulate chemical reactions and impact the colour of planets and behaviour of their surfaces. The game is already amazing as it is though, it's a gravity and a climate and a massive epic explosion simulator! Seriously worth the price!

content:
16, 2016
Early Access Review
								(21/9+10 ign mlg) hitler sim 2016Before my first contact with this game, I had a life, a wife, two kids, a nice house and also a car. Then, I met Universe Sandbox. This game was exactly what I needed to be happy. I am a new guy now. My undies are always brown as I am so addicted that I can't leave my chair. My house has trash and rotten food all over the floor because I can't stop playing this. I am not sure, but looks like my wife went away with my children and my car. I am all by myself now. No time to care about this, tho. This is the most amazing sandbox game ever made. I am still looking for the sand, tho. 2,222 hours in and no sand yet. But I hope it will appear someday. I will keep looking for it.It's the best game ever made. The whole mankind needs to know about this masterpiece. It's a huge universe building tool where you can even make planets crash and bring disaster and death everywhere. This is what I call bloody. If you think that The Witcher 3 or Fallout 4 are the best games ever made, go learn a bit more about games and figure out that Universe Sandbox is the ultimate masterpiece. It's better than sex.I still wonder where the sand is. 10/10 Would ruin my whole life again. No Regrets.*It's not serious, in case you are wondering*The game is pretty fun. Worth buying.

content:
11, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'll be honest here. I LOVE science; especially space. In fact I want to be an astronomer. This game is realy cool, and I love sandboxes, but I think there's TOO much freedom. I'm not the kind of person who screams in terror or excitment when two celestial bodies collide together. The game is good in the fact of realism. For example, I learned about a star that's 11.5 km across from playing this game. That is very interesting to me, to learn that a star can be that small, but honestly, I could've learned that anyway, without paying $25 for it. It's just hard for me to stay interested in the game, but whoever's reading this might be different.

content:
15, 2016
Early Access Review
								Awesome to turn on when you just want to relax. Watch how the universe works and of course, if you want to, throw bowling balls at the moon, or throw a Sun at Jupiter (DISCLAIMER: Do not try at home). For the money I paid, this is worth it by far.You can take super high resolution photos too (~5x larger than 4K!) I've become satisfied just zooming in on the photos I've taken. Make your own star systems if you wish too, you can create any system in this game. Yes, even colliding galaxies. Do you want to see colliding galaxies? If so, that purchase button is for you.

content:
, 2016
Early Access Review
								The first calculation comes from Kepler's Third Law (shown below), where 'G'  is Newton's Gravitational Constant.The period, 'P', is the orbital period of the exoplanet, and comes directly from the measured period using, for example, the transit or radial velocity detection methods (Detection Methods page). The mass of the star, 'M', was calculated above using the mass-luminosity relationship of stars. Finally, the mass of the exoplanet, 'm', in the equation can be ignored, since it is much smaller than the mass of the parent star. As an example, since the Sun is about three hundred thousand times heavier than the Earth, ignoring the mass of the Earth in this calculation woud introduce an error of less than 0.001%. The equation can be solved for the only remaining variable which is the orbital radius, 'a'. Once the orbital radius has been determined, the mass of the planet can be calculated using Newton's Law of Gravitation shown below. Here, 'G' is once again the Gravitational constant, 'm1' is the mass of the parent star, 'r' is the orbital radius (this was 'a' in the equation above), and 'Fg' is the force of gravity betwe- Oh, the game? Yeah, its fine.

content:
13, 2016
Early Access Review
								I love Universal Sandbox and have had lots of fun with it through the years.  I am glad that I bought into Universal Sandbox 2 to help it's developers out.  No matter what happens with the program, it is money well spent for someone who loves astronomy.  Initially, I struggle with the interface, not that it is bad, it just doesn't feel quite right.  I look for menus at the top of the screen not the bottom (at least in the PC World) and I depend on right-clicking for guidance and fail-safe options when I get lost.  In this program, Right-Clicking does nothing, a major oversight.  There is no obvious way to set the date.  In my way of thinking, that should always be an option since my greatest interest on any given night is how the universe looks from my back yard.  I have ipad apps that do this better and I expect more from a well-developed PC program like this.  This user is not sure why it always has to start on some date in 2014 and moves forward.  The developers were quick to respond to my comments in a very positive way.  That in itself makes me put it on the recommend list.  They are aware of these issues and indicate that they will work to address the program's shortcomings.  Now that I sort of have the interface figured out, there are many fun things to do with this program.  Looking forward to using it as-is and for improvements in the future.If you love astronomy, you will enjoy this if you don't mind a few oddities and rough edges.

It makes me really think about, and become highly interested in, the cosmos, and for someone who gets D grades in physics, that's a kinda big deal....

content:
13, 2016
Early Access Review
 Oh, is this amazing! I have always been fascinated by Space, and everything to do with it. The vastness, the possibilities and the interesting features it has, waiting to be found and explored...Now, while I can't exactly go into space and discover it all, this game is a great alternitive! While, not so much on the exploration side of things, it makes it possible to experience almost everything space has to offer. Want to watch the Moon crash into the Earth, go right ahead. Smash ten, smash twenty, how every many you like. Or, maybe terraform Mars. Get it to the point where it has vast oceans, ice caps and even life! See how similar you can make the planets to Earth...Or, turn Jupiter into a star...Or allow Pluto to achieve revenge by turning it into a Black Hole. It's up to you! I have played and do own the original Universe Sandbox, and I have to say: This Sequal (i guess you could call it :P) just improves and adds to the original, beyond measure. It is an absolutely beautifle game, with increadibly realistic physics and is a great game to constantly come back to. Also, the Music is just perfect. As soon as the music comes on, I am instantaneously in deep thought about what the Universe may behold...(Also, get to smash Uranus ;)  )100% recommend this amazing experience!

content:
er 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is really incredible. I have often daydreamed about what it would be like to die and float through space to see, in person, the beauty that is space. This game gives you that sensation in a way only the experiene itself can dmonstrate. This must be what it would feel like to be a God.Cons: The VR version doesn't have many of the features that are available in the regular version. I presume they will eventually be added as an update. Black holes, for example, can't be added in VR mode, but within VR you can go to your desktop and add them into the scene manually and then go back into VR mode and see them. (seems like an easy fix that will hopefully be added in future updates).

content:
3
Early Access Review
								I have played this game both in VR, and out.  It is great both ways.  Lots of fun to tinker around with, explore different and fun experiments in space using all of the objects we're familiar with.  The experience especially comes alive in VR, since you can witness collisions in first-person and stand on the surface of all the great gas giants and whatever else you want.  Even out of VR this provides enough fun and content to easily justify the price.The best feature about this is that there are many pre-set loadouts, from individual planets, to the solar system, to dozens of collisions.  So you don't have to spend the hours to customize and make your own arrangement of things just to see "what if" or start experimenting on the solar system.  This to me is what makes the game good.

content:
3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Universe Sandbox 2 isn't really a game as much as it is a toy. Don't let that discourage you though, because it's still one of the best interactive experiences I've ever had. In Universe Sandbox 2, you can create you own solar systems, galaxies even, using an incredibly easy to use, yet powerful interface. You can tweak any parameter of the simulation to your will; your imagination is the only limit. The game's physics model is one of the most realistic ones that I have seen in a game. It's also incredibly fun to load the default solar system and see what kinds of apocalyptic scenarios you can enact.9/10- This game made me realize why I'm not God.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
er 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Started game.Saw Saturn.Why doesn't Saturn have any rings?Add rings to Saturn.Add Moons to Saturn.Throw a couple moons into Saturn.Saturn catches fire planetwide."Houston we have a problem."Figure that maybe Jupiter would have a solution.Look at Jupiter.Jupiter has no ring, no moons, nothing.Give Jupiter what he deserves.But guess what? Budget cuts (aka already lagging out), he has to borrow Saturn's moons if he wants any.Jupiter approaches Saturn, and a battle of cosmic scale commences.Their rings collide into each other as they get closer and closer, Saturn's moons are deorbitting and Jupiter is now engulfed in flames as well. This is a sight to behold, worthy only of gods.Oh wait that's my job.Watch as the planets collide in real-time.Suddenly, Jupiter just eats Saturn. Jupiter is a glowing ball almost as bright as the sun, now surrounded by a spiral display of asteroids that make up it's rings as it eats up Saturns moons.Jupiter you're not supposed to do that.Jupiter grows bigger and bigger, until it begins to affect the orbital patterns of other planets.Speed up game to a few hours a second, the rocky planets are torn apart and the outter gas giants are coming towards my Frankenstein's monster named, "New Jupitus 3."New Jupitus 3 grows as it consumes our solar system.After a few tweaks in it's mass, New Jupitus now rivals the power of that of the sun, having ascended into it's new existential tier as Star.Sun and New Jupitus inch closer and closer to each other, until years later they collide.New Jupitus only grows stronger.Little brother walks in."Hey, can you make planets bigger?"I hatch an idea.Edit the planet's mass by removing the decimal and ending a hoard of zeroes to the end of the number.Planet immediately becomes a galaxy sized black hole.See this red stuff around it that reminds me of fire, so boost the temperature of my new dimensional portal.Add endless zeroes to end of temperature number.Computer begins to overheat and spew dust out of the disk tray.What in tarnation is going on.Computer screen freezes, blacks out, blue screens, shuts off.Computer won't turn on.Most realistic game, heated up supermassive black hole and ended up frying my CPU, 10/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
8, 2016
Early Access Review
								Universe Sandbox is simply amazing. Unlike other games in the space genre, Universe Sandbox lets you metaphorically become god. The attention to detail is absolutely stunning. For example, increasing the sun's gravitational pull will draw earth towards it. As it gets closer you can see the oceans evaporating and the temperature of the planet increasing until it burns up and is destroyed. When earth isn't being consumed by suns, black holes, or teapots (yes teapots), you can see further detail in its rotation such as how all the lights of the cities turn on when facing away from the sun. It gives you a sense of life... before you cause a second ice age. I've just gone on about earth. There's so much more to this game. Want to decrease the suns mass? Go for it. Want to cause a supernova? Do it. Want to collide galaxies in real time? Well if you have the time why not. The game is one of my favorites. If you like space or generally just being a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on a cosmic level, do yourself a favor and get this game. It's well worth the money. As a side note, if you have a modern laptop, this game runs well on those too due to the superb optimization. My laptop is 7 years old and it still runs well. Alright, I'm going to stop rambling now, but don't leave just yet. Scroll up and click buy right now. Even if you don't have a credit card. If you're a kid tell your parents RobBop demanded you to buy it. In fact bring them here. Parents? If you're here, little Timmy promised to do twice the amount of housework if you buy this game. Do it, you won't regret it.

content:
3
Early Access Review
								I have played this game both in VR, and out.  It is great both ways.  Lots of fun to tinker around with, explore different and fun experiments in space using all of the objects we're familiar with.  The experience especially comes alive in VR, since you can witness collisions in first-person and stand on the surface of all the great gas giants and whatever else you want.  Even out of VR this provides enough fun and content to easily justify the price.The best feature about this is that there are many pre-set loadouts, from individual planets, to the solar system, to dozens of collisions.  So you don't have to spend the hours to customize and make your own arrangement of things just to see "what if" or start experimenting on the solar system.  This to me is what makes the game good.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
8, 2016
Early Access Review
								Universe Sandbox is simply amazing. Unlike other games in the space genre, Universe Sandbox lets you metaphorically become god. The attention to detail is absolutely stunning. For example, increasing the sun's gravitational pull will draw earth towards it. As it gets closer you can see the oceans evaporating and the temperature of the planet increasing until it burns up and is destroyed. When earth isn't being consumed by suns, black holes, or teapots (yes teapots), you can see further detail in its rotation such as how all the lights of the cities turn on when facing away from the sun. It gives you a sense of life... before you cause a second ice age. I've just gone on about earth. There's so much more to this game. Want to decrease the suns mass? Go for it. Want to cause a supernova? Do it. Want to collide galaxies in real time? Well if you have the time why not. The game is one of my favorites. If you like space or generally just being a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on a cosmic level, do yourself a favor and get this game. It's well worth the money. As a side note, if you have a modern laptop, this game runs well on those too due to the superb optimization. My laptop is 7 years old and it still runs well. Alright, I'm going to stop rambling now, but don't leave just yet. Scroll up and click buy right now. Even if you don't have a credit card. If you're a kid tell your parents RobBop demanded you to buy it. In fact bring them here. Parents? If you're here, little Timmy promised to do twice the amount of housework if you buy this game. Do it, you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
9, 2016
Early Access Review
								I haven't spent too long with Universe Sandbox 2, but I can tell you from the precious time I have spent with it that this is an absolute must-buy if your brain capacity can support games of a grander scale than "kill the things."It's a masterpiece. Visually stunning, the planets and stars are beautifully detailed. I particularly enjoy gazing at the Earth, admiring the textures and shadows: it really is that good looking.The physics are both accurate and fun to play around with, I've had endless fun setting up my own solar systems only to make the star go supernova and spawn a supermassive black hole at the centre for the sheer hell of it. It really is a universe sandbox, boot it up and mould space to your liking.The scientific depth of this game is almost ludicrous. Every single aspect of anything in the universe can be observed or changed, and I mean EVERY ASPECT. There's stuff here I've never even heard of, let alone understood. The attention to detail here is astounding.Overall? Wonderful. Looks good, plays well, scientifically accurate and overall just plain fun. It's fun both for casuals who just want to play with the galaxy and explore astrophysics, and it's also fun for hardcore physics buffs who understand every single variable. Congrats devs, you hit the nail on the head in my opinion. I look forward to spending many more hours in this wonderful game :)

content:
, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game was a lot more complicated, and involved then I had expected. I LOVE the dynamic sound track, to me that made this game. Also, I suggest to anyone playing to go to the largest scale, set two rocky bodies on a collision course, zoom in to one of the planets surfaces, and in the final aproach, set the time to scale. Watching worlds collide from a first person perspective is awe inspiring.There are something things that could be improved or added. Like the ability to snap to objects and name or lable them. I had a hard time trying to set up a star/ planet combination. I'd ran into a couple of glitches that sent me across the universe, never to see my planet again. Also, it would be nice to be able to reverse time. Also this game would probably consume ALL of my free time if there was a way to set up or follow an ecosystem. Or have the ability to create life and watch it evolve maybe had a stats bar with the type of life and its progress or something to that effect. Overall; As is, the game is fun. But I can see great potenial in this. I'm excited to see where this goes. That and who ever wrote the music score for this game should get a pat on the back

content:
y 6
Early Access Review
								This sandbox is a pure scientific game. I would not recommend the game to those gamers who think that science is boring. For others I want to say - the game is incredible. You can use various planets, stars, novas, comets etc. to build the Universe you like. You can also modify different parameters of objects, such as mass, density, angular velocity and many more. I was amuzed when I changed the mass, and it was automatically recalculated into a mass of a bigger object (e.g. mass of the Earth into mass of Jupiter). A challenging aspect of this game - you have to learn physics and astrophysics otherwise you will crash a model in seconds. My respect to devs, you've made a great job.

content:
er 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								So I've been playing around in Universe sandbox making my own life-filled solar system, and theres a little thing that bugs me. If I create a planet with a nice constant temperature, it'll have a effective temperature of like -270 degrees. Now this Isn't a problem while in game, but if I leave the simulation and reload it, the planet will be completely frozen, even if it's really close to the sun. I've sorta come to the conclusion that effective temperatures mean nothing, and if they actually mean something, I don't know what it is. It's just a little annoying that I have to set the temperature of each planet back to what it was every time I load the simulation. The weird thing is though, is that for the remainder of time im in the simulation, it'll stay at the nice life-supporting temperature, until of course I reload the simulation, to which It'll reset to absurdly cold temperatures. To be honest, I;m not even entirely sure if this even is a bug or not, but if it is a feature of the game, It'd be nice to know why it happens. Other than that, I don't really have any more complaints about Universe Sandbox, it's a great game, and I would definately recomend it.

content:
25, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is an excellent simulation on the universe. You can set up your own simulation and see what happens or just use one of the many pre made situations. Go for an educational experience as you look at the planet as the temperature increases, as you tilt the axis, or even look at one of 50,000 celestial bodies.Or, say hang it and chuck the moon and the Earth and laugh manically at the destruction!It runs really smoothly has some nice sound design. However they could implement a way to increase the UI size for higher resolutions, running it in 4K and the UI become nigh on unreadable. However this is in the grand scheme of things is minor, I've only played it for about 2 hours today and I had so much fum. Here's a video showing my first impressions:

content:
er 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Do you have a terrible imagination and little to no curiosity as to how physics works? Do you hate the laws of gravitation and show disdain for the wonders of the universe? Then this game isn't for you. Don't get it.If, on the other hand, you love space, or just really want to make pluto devour the universe: Buy it. This game is wonderful and a fantastic sequel to the first game. The developers know what they're doing and have done a lot of research in order to make this game as accurate as it is. It's a sandbox game, so it's only as fun as you can make it. There's no plot, no main theme, no goal (although the music is pretty great) so go ahead and make the earth plunge into a state of warmth that would surely wipe out all life, or replace the sun with a black hole. You could even terraform mars if you wanted.Best game 10/10 IGN
